     44     <h1>
     45       UTF8-CPP: UTF-8 with C++ in a Portable Way
     46     </h1>
     47     <p>
     48       <a href="https://sourceforge.net/projects/utfcpp">The Sourceforge project page</a>
     49     </p>

     96     <h2 id="introduction">
     97       Introduction
     98     </h2>
     99     <p>
    100       Many C++ developers miss an easy and portable way of handling Unicode encoded
    101       strings. The original C++ Standard (known as C++98 or C++03) is Unicode agnostic.
    102       C++11 provides some support for Unicode on core language and library level:
    103       u8, u, and U character and string literals, char16_t and char32_t character types,
    104       u16string and u32string library classes, and codecvt support for conversions 
    105       between Unicode encoding forms.
    106       In the meantime, developers use third party libraries like ICU, OS specific capabilities, or simply
    107       roll out their own solutions.
    108     </p>
    109     <p>
    110       In order to easily handle UTF-8 encoded Unicode strings, I came up with a small
    111       generic library. For anybody used to work with STL algorithms and iterators, it should be
    112       easy and natural to use. The code is freely available for any purpose - check out
    113       the license at the beginning of the utf8.h file. If you run into
    114       bugs or performance issues, please let me know and I'll do my best to address them.
    115     </p>
    116     <p>
    117       The purpose of this article is not to offer an introduction to Unicode in general,
    118       and UTF-8 in particular. If you are not familiar with Unicode, be sure to check out
    119       <a href="http://www.unicode.org/">Unicode Home Page</a> or some other source of
    120       information for Unicode. Also, it is not my aim to advocate the use of UTF-8
    121       encoded strings in C++ programs; if you want to handle UTF-8 encoded strings from
    122       C++, I am sure you have good reasons for it.
    123     </p>
    124     <h2 id="examples">
    125       Examples of use
    126     </h2>
    127     <h3 id="introsample">
    128       Introductionary Sample
    129     </h3>
    130     <p>
    131       To illustrate the use of the library, let's start with a small but complete program 
    132       that opens a file containing UTF-8 encoded text, reads it line by line, checks each line
    133       for invalid UTF-8 byte sequences, and converts it to UTF-16 encoding and back to UTF-8:
    134     </p>
    135 <pre>
    136 <span class="preprocessor">#include &lt;fstream&gt;</span>
    137 <span class="preprocessor">#include &lt;iostream&gt;</span>
    138 <span class="preprocessor">#include &lt;string&gt;</span>
    139 <span class="preprocessor">#include &lt;vector&gt;</span>
    140 <span class="preprocessor">#include "utf8.h"</span>
    141 <span class="keyword">using namespace</span> std;
    142 <span class="keyword">int</span> main(<span class="keyword">int</span> argc, <span class="keyword">char</span>** argv)
    143 {
    144     <span class="keyword">if</span> (argc != <span class="literal">2</span>) {
    145         cout &lt;&lt; <span class="literal">"\nUsage: docsample filename\n"</span>;
    146         <span class="keyword">return</span> <span class="literal">0</span>;
    147     }
    148 
    149     <span class="keyword">const char</span>* test_file_path = argv[1];
    150     <span class="comment">// Open the test file (contains UTF-8 encoded text)</span>
    151     ifstream fs8(test_file_path);
    152     <span class="keyword">if</span> (!fs8.is_open()) {
    153     cout &lt;&lt; <span class=
    154 "literal">"Could not open "</span> &lt;&lt; test_file_path &lt;&lt; endl;
    155     <span class="keyword">return</span> <span class="literal">0</span>;
    156     }
    157 
    158     <span class="keyword">unsigned</span> line_count = <span class="literal">1</span>;
    159     string line;
    160     <span class="comment">// Play with all the lines in the file</span>
    161     <span class="keyword">while</span> (getline(fs8, line)) {
    162        <span class="comment">// check for invalid utf-8 (for a simple yes/no check, there is also utf8::is_valid function)</span>
    163         string::iterator end_it = utf8::find_invalid(line.begin(), line.end());
    164         <span class="keyword">if</span> (end_it != line.end()) {
    165             cout &lt;&lt; <span class=
    166 "literal">"Invalid UTF-8 encoding detected at line "</span> &lt;&lt; line_count &lt;&lt; <span
    167  class="literal">"\n"</span>;
    168             cout &lt;&lt; <span class=
    169 "literal">"This part is fine: "</span> &lt;&lt; string(line.begin(), end_it) &lt;&lt; <span
    170  class="literal">"\n"</span>;
    171         }
    172 
    173         <span class="comment">// Get the line length (at least for the valid part)</span>
    174         <span class="keyword">int</span> length = utf8::distance(line.begin(), end_it);
    175         cout &lt;&lt; <span class=
    176 "literal">"Length of line "</span> &lt;&lt; line_count &lt;&lt; <span class=
    177 "literal">" is "</span> &lt;&lt; length &lt;&lt;  <span class="literal">"\n"</span>;
    178 
    179         <span class="comment">// Convert it to utf-16</span>
    180         vector&lt;unsigned short&gt; utf16line;
    181         utf8::utf8to16(line.begin(), end_it, back_inserter(utf16line));
    182 
    183         <span class="comment">// And back to utf-8</span>
    184         string utf8line; 
    185         utf8::utf16to8(utf16line.begin(), utf16line.end(), back_inserter(utf8line));
    186 
    187         <span class="comment">// Confirm that the conversion went OK:</span>
    188         <span class="keyword">if</span> (utf8line != string(line.begin(), end_it))
    189             cout &lt;&lt; <span class=
    190 "literal">"Error in UTF-16 conversion at line: "</span> &lt;&lt; line_count &lt;&lt; <span
    191  class="literal">"\n"</span>;        
    192 
    193         line_count++;
    194     }
    195     <span class="keyword">return</span> <span class="literal">0</span>;
    196 }
    197 </pre>
    198     <p>
    199       In the previous code sample, for each line we performed
    200       a detection of invalid UTF-8 sequences with <code>find_invalid</code>; the number
    201       of characters (more precisely - the number of Unicode code points, including the end
    202       of line and even BOM if there is one) in each line was
    203       determined with a use of <code>utf8::distance</code>; finally, we have converted
    204       each line to UTF-16 encoding with <code>utf8to16</code> and back to UTF-8 with
    205       <code>utf16to8</code>.
    206     </p>
    207     <h3 id="validfile">Checking if a file contains valid UTF-8 text</h3>
    208 <p>
    209 Here is a function that checks whether the content of a file is valid UTF-8 encoded text without
    210 reading the content into the memory:
    211 </p>
    212 <pre>    
    213 <span class="keyword">bool</span> valid_utf8_file(i<span class="keyword">const char</span>* file_name)
    214 {
    215     ifstream ifs(file_name);
    216     <span class="keyword">if</span> (!ifs)
    217         <span class="keyword">return false</span>; <span class="comment">// even better, throw here</span>
    218 
    219     istreambuf_iterator&lt;<span class="keyword">char</span>&gt; it(ifs.rdbuf());
    220     istreambuf_iterator&lt;<span class="keyword">char</span>&gt; eos;
    221 
    222     <span class="keyword">return</span> utf8::is_valid(it, eos);
    223 }
    224 </pre>
    225 <p>
    226 Because the function <code>utf8::is_valid()</code> works with input iterators, we were able
    227 to pass an <code>istreambuf_iterator</code> to it and read the content of the file directly 
    228 without loading it to the memory first.</p>
    229 <p>
    230 Note that other functions that take input iterator arguments can be used in a similar way. For
    231 instance, to read the content of a UTF-8 encoded text file and convert the text to UTF-16, just 
    232 do something like:
    233 </p>
    234 <pre>
    235     utf8::utf8to16(it, eos, back_inserter(u16string));
    236 </pre>
    237     <h3 id="fixinvalid">Ensure that a string contains valid UTF-8 text</h3>
    238 <p>
    239 If we have some text that "probably" contains UTF-8 encoded text and we want to
    240 replace any invalid UTF-8 sequence with a replacement character, something like 
    241 the following function may be used:
    242 </p>
    243 <pre>
    244 <span class="keyword">void</span> fix_utf8_string(std::string&amp; str)
    245 {
    246     std::string temp;
    247     utf8::replace_invalid(str.begin(), str.end(), back_inserter(temp));
    248     str = temp;
    249 }
    250 </pre>
    251 <p>The function will replace any invalid UTF-8 sequence with a Unicode replacement character. 
    252 There is an overloaded function that enables the caller to supply their own replacement character.
    253 </p>
    254     <h2 id="reference">
    255       Reference
    256     </h2>
    257     <h3 id="funutf8">
    258       Functions From utf8 Namespace
    259     </h3>
    260     <h4>
    261       utf8::append
    262     </h4>
    263     <p class="version">
    264     Available in version 1.0 and later.
    265     </p>
    266     <p>
    267       Encodes a 32 bit code point as a UTF-8 sequence of octets and appends the sequence
    268       to a UTF-8 string.
    269     </p>
    270 <pre>
    271 <span class="keyword">template</span> &lt;<span class=
    272 "keyword">typename</span> octet_iterator&gt;
    273 octet_iterator append(uint32_t cp, octet_iterator result);
    274    
    275 </pre>
    276     <p>
    277 	  <code>octet_iterator</code>: an output iterator.<br>
    278       <code>cp</code>: a 32 bit integer representing a code point to append to the
    279       sequence.<br>
    280        <code>result</code>: an output iterator to the place in the sequence where to
    281       append the code point.<br>
    282        <span class="return_value">Return value</span>: an iterator pointing to the place
    283       after the newly appended sequence.
    284     </p>
    285     <p>
    286       Example of use:
    287     </p>
    288 <pre>
    289 <span class="keyword">unsigned char</span> u[<span class="literal">5</span>] = {<span
    290 class="literal">0</span>,<span class="literal">0</span>,<span class=
    291 "literal">0</span>,<span class="literal">0</span>,<span class="literal">0</span>};
    292 <span class="keyword">unsigned char</span>* end = append(<span class=
    293 "literal">0x0448</span>, u);
    294 assert (u[<span class="literal">0</span>] == <span class=
    295 "literal">0xd1</span> &amp;&amp; u[<span class="literal">1</span>] == <span class=
    296 "literal">0x88</span> &amp;&amp; u[<span class="literal">2</span>] == <span class=
    297 "literal">0</span> &amp;&amp; u[<span class="literal">3</span>] == <span class=
    298 "literal">0</span> &amp;&amp; u[<span class="literal">4</span>] == <span class=
    299 "literal">0</span>);
    300 </pre>
    301     <p>
    302       Note that <code>append</code> does not allocate any memory - it is the burden of
    303       the caller to make sure there is enough memory allocated for the operation. To make
    304       things more interesting, <code>append</code> can add anywhere between 1 and 4
    305       octets to the sequence. In practice, you would most often want to use
    306       <code>std::back_inserter</code> to ensure that the necessary memory is allocated.
    307     </p>
    308     <p>
    309       In case of an invalid code point, a <code>utf8::invalid_code_point</code> exception
    310       is thrown.
    311     </p>
    312     <h4>
    313       utf8::next
    314     </h4>
    315     <p class="version">
    316     Available in version 1.0 and later.
    317     </p>
    318     <p>
    319       Given the iterator to the beginning of the UTF-8 sequence, it returns the code
    320       point and moves the iterator to the next position.
    321     </p>
    322 <pre>
    323 <span class="keyword">template</span> &lt;<span class=
    324 "keyword">typename</span> octet_iterator&gt; 
    325 uint32_t next(octet_iterator&amp; it, octet_iterator end);
    326    
    327 </pre>
    328     <p>
    329 	  <code>octet_iterator</code>: an input iterator.<br>
    330       <code>it</code>: a reference to an iterator pointing to the beginning of an UTF-8
    331       encoded code point. After the function returns, it is incremented to point to the
    332       beginning of the next code point.<br>
    333        <code>end</code>: end of the UTF-8 sequence to be processed. If <code>it</code>
    334       gets equal to <code>end</code> during the extraction of a code point, an
    335       <code>utf8::not_enough_room</code> exception is thrown.<br>
    336        <span class="return_value">Return value</span>: the 32 bit representation of the
    337       processed UTF-8 code point.
    338     </p>
    339     <p>
    340       Example of use:
    341     </p>
    342 <pre>
    343 <span class="keyword">char</span>* twochars = <span class=
    344 "literal">"\xe6\x97\xa5\xd1\x88"</span>;
    345 <span class="keyword">char</span>* w = twochars;
    346 <span class="keyword">int</span> cp = next(w, twochars + <span class="literal">6</span>);
    347 assert (cp == <span class="literal">0x65e5</span>);
    348 assert (w == twochars + <span class="literal">3</span>);
    349 </pre>
    350     <p>
    351       This function is typically used to iterate through a UTF-8 encoded string.
    352     </p>
    353     <p>
    354       In case of an invalid UTF-8 seqence, a <code>utf8::invalid_utf8</code> exception is
    355       thrown.
    356     </p>
    357     <h4>
    358       utf8::peek_next
    359     </h4>
    360     <p class="version">
    361     Available in version 2.1 and later.
    362     </p>
    363     <p>
    364       Given the iterator to the beginning of the UTF-8 sequence, it returns the code
    365       point for the following sequence without changing the value of the iterator. 
    366     </p>
    367 <pre>
    368 <span class="keyword">template</span> &lt;<span class=
    369 "keyword">typename</span> octet_iterator&gt; 
    370 uint32_t peek_next(octet_iterator it, octet_iterator end);
    371    
    372 </pre>
    373     <p>
    374 	  <code>octet_iterator</code>: an input iterator.<br>
    375       <code>it</code>: an iterator pointing to the beginning of an UTF-8
    376       encoded code point.<br>
    377        <code>end</code>: end of the UTF-8 sequence to be processed. If <code>it</code>
    378       gets equal to <code>end</code> during the extraction of a code point, an
    379       <code>utf8::not_enough_room</code> exception is thrown.<br>
    380        <span class="return_value">Return value</span>: the 32 bit representation of the
    381       processed UTF-8 code point.
    382     </p>
    383     <p>
    384       Example of use:
    385     </p>
    386 <pre>
    387 <span class="keyword">char</span>* twochars = <span class=
    388 "literal">"\xe6\x97\xa5\xd1\x88"</span>;
    389 <span class="keyword">char</span>* w = twochars;
    390 <span class="keyword">int</span> cp = peek_next(w, twochars + <span class="literal">6</span>);
    391 assert (cp == <span class="literal">0x65e5</span>);
    392 assert (w == twochars);
    393 </pre>
    394     <p>
    395       In case of an invalid UTF-8 seqence, a <code>utf8::invalid_utf8</code> exception is
    396       thrown.
    397     </p>
    398     <h4>
    399       utf8::prior
    400     </h4>
    401     <p class="version">
    402     Available in version 1.02 and later.
    403     </p>
    404     <p>
    405       Given a reference to an iterator pointing to an octet in a UTF-8 sequence, it
    406       decreases the iterator until it hits the beginning of the previous UTF-8 encoded
    407       code point and returns the 32 bits representation of the code point.
    408     </p>
    409 <pre>
    410 <span class="keyword">template</span> &lt;<span class=
    411 "keyword">typename</span> octet_iterator&gt; 
    412 uint32_t prior(octet_iterator&amp; it, octet_iterator start);
    413    
    414 </pre>
    415     <p>
    416 	  <code>octet_iterator</code>: a bidirectional iterator.<br>
    417       <code>it</code>: a reference pointing to an octet within a UTF-8 encoded string.
    418       After the function returns, it is decremented to point to the beginning of the
    419       previous code point.<br>
    420        <code>start</code>: an iterator to the beginning of the sequence where the search
    421       for the beginning of a code point is performed. It is a
    422       safety measure to prevent passing the beginning of the string in the search for a
    423       UTF-8 lead octet.<br>
    424        <span class="return_value">Return value</span>: the 32 bit representation of the
    425       previous code point.
    426     </p>
    427     <p>
    428       Example of use:
    429     </p>
    430 <pre>
    431 <span class="keyword">char</span>* twochars = <span class=
    432 "literal">"\xe6\x97\xa5\xd1\x88"</span>;
    433 <span class="keyword">unsigned char</span>* w = twochars + <span class=
    434 "literal">3</span>;
    435 <span class="keyword">int</span> cp = prior (w, twochars);
    436 assert (cp == <span class="literal">0x65e5</span>);
    437 assert (w == twochars);
    438 </pre>
    439     <p> 
    440       This function has two purposes: one is two iterate backwards through a UTF-8
    441       encoded string. Note that it is usually a better idea to iterate forward instead,
    442       since <code>utf8::next</code> is faster. The second purpose is to find a beginning
    443       of a UTF-8 sequence if we have a random position within a string. Note that in that
    444       case <code>utf8::prior</code> may not detect an invalid UTF-8 sequence in some scenarios:
    445       for instance if there are superfluous trail octets, it will just skip them.
    446     </p> 
    447     <p>
    448       <code>it</code> will typically point to the beginning of
    449       a code point, and <code>start</code> will point to the
    450       beginning of the string to ensure we don't go backwards too far. <code>it</code> is
    451       decreased until it points to a lead UTF-8 octet, and then the UTF-8 sequence
    452       beginning with that octet is decoded to a 32 bit representation and returned.
    453     </p>
    454     <p>
    455       In case <code>start</code> is reached before a UTF-8 lead octet is hit, or if an
    456       invalid UTF-8 sequence is started by the lead octet, an <code>invalid_utf8</code>
    457       exception is thrown.
    458     </p>
    459     <p>In case <code>start</code> equals <code>it</code>, a <code>not_enough_room</code>
    460       exception is thrown.
    461     <h4>
    462       utf8::previous
    463     </h4>
    464     <p class="version">
    465     Deprecated in version 1.02 and later.
    466     </p>
    467     <p>
    468       Given a reference to an iterator pointing to an octet in a UTF-8 seqence, it
    469       decreases the iterator until it hits the beginning of the previous UTF-8 encoded
    470       code point and returns the 32 bits representation of the code point.
    471     </p>
    472 <pre>
    473 <span class="keyword">template</span> &lt;<span class=
    474 "keyword">typename</span> octet_iterator&gt; 
    475 uint32_t previous(octet_iterator&amp; it, octet_iterator pass_start);
    476    
    477 </pre>
    478     <p>
    479 	  <code>octet_iterator</code>: a random access iterator.<br>
    480       <code>it</code>: a reference pointing to an octet within a UTF-8 encoded string.
    481       After the function returns, it is decremented to point to the beginning of the
    482       previous code point.<br>
    483        <code>pass_start</code>: an iterator to the point in the sequence where the search
    484       for the beginning of a code point is aborted if no result was reached. It is a
    485       safety measure to prevent passing the beginning of the string in the search for a
    486       UTF-8 lead octet.<br>
    487        <span class="return_value">Return value</span>: the 32 bit representation of the
    488       previous code point.
    489     </p>
    490     <p>
    491       Example of use:
    492     </p>
    493 <pre>
    494 <span class="keyword">char</span>* twochars = <span class=
    495 "literal">"\xe6\x97\xa5\xd1\x88"</span>;
    496 <span class="keyword">unsigned char</span>* w = twochars + <span class=
    497 "literal">3</span>;
    498 <span class="keyword">int</span> cp = previous (w, twochars - <span class=
    499 "literal">1</span>);
    500 assert (cp == <span class="literal">0x65e5</span>);
    501 assert (w == twochars);
    502 </pre>
    503     <p>
    504       <code>utf8::previous</code> is deprecated, and <code>utf8::prior</code> should
    505       be used instead, although the existing code can continue using this function.
    506       The problem is the parameter <code>pass_start</code> that points to the position
    507       just before the beginning of the sequence. Standard containers don't have the 
    508       concept of "pass start" and the function can not be used with their iterators.
    509     </p>
    510     <p>
    511       <code>it</code> will typically point to the beginning of
    512       a code point, and <code>pass_start</code> will point to the octet just before the
    513       beginning of the string to ensure we don't go backwards too far. <code>it</code> is
    514       decreased until it points to a lead UTF-8 octet, and then the UTF-8 sequence
    515       beginning with that octet is decoded to a 32 bit representation and returned.
    516     </p>
    517     <p>
    518       In case <code>pass_start</code> is reached before a UTF-8 lead octet is hit, or if an
    519       invalid UTF-8 sequence is started by the lead octet, an <code>invalid_utf8</code>
    520       exception is thrown
    521     </p>
    522     <h4>
    523       utf8::advance
    524     </h4>
    525     <p class="version">
    526     Available in version 1.0 and later.
    527     </p>
    528     <p>
    529       Advances an iterator by the specified number of code points within an UTF-8
    530       sequence.
    531     </p>
    532 <pre>
    533 <span class="keyword">template</span> &lt;<span class=
    534 "keyword">typename</span> octet_iterator, typename distance_type&gt; 
    535 <span class=
    536 "keyword">void</span> advance (octet_iterator&amp; it, distance_type n, octet_iterator end);
    537    
    538 </pre>
    539     <p>
    540       <code>octet_iterator</code>: an input iterator.<br>
    541       <code>distance_type</code>: an integral type convertible to <code>octet_iterator</code>'s difference type.<br>
    542       <code>it</code>: a reference to an iterator pointing to the beginning of an UTF-8
    543       encoded code point. After the function returns, it is incremented to point to the
    544       nth following code point.<br>
    545        <code>n</code>: a positive integer that shows how many code points we want to
    546       advance.<br>
    547        <code>end</code>: end of the UTF-8 sequence to be processed. If <code>it</code>
    548       gets equal to <code>end</code> during the extraction of a code point, an
    549       <code>utf8::not_enough_room</code> exception is thrown.<br>
    550     </p>
    551     <p>
    552       Example of use:
    553     </p>
    554 <pre>
    555 <span class="keyword">char</span>* twochars = <span class=
    556 "literal">"\xe6\x97\xa5\xd1\x88"</span>;
    557 <span class="keyword">unsigned char</span>* w = twochars;
    558 advance (w, <span class="literal">2</span>, twochars + <span class="literal">6</span>);
    559 assert (w == twochars + <span class="literal">5</span>);
    560 </pre>
    561     <p>
    562       This function works only "forward". In case of a negative <code>n</code>, there is
    563       no effect.
    564     </p>
    565     <p>
    566       In case of an invalid code point, a <code>utf8::invalid_code_point</code> exception
    567       is thrown.
    568     </p>
    569     <h4>
    570       utf8::distance
    571     </h4>
    572     <p class="version">
    573     Available in version 1.0 and later.
    574     </p>
    575     <p>
    576       Given the iterators to two UTF-8 encoded code points in a seqence, returns the
    577       number of code points between them.
    578     </p>
    579 <pre>
    580 <span class="keyword">template</span> &lt;<span class=
    581 "keyword">typename</span> octet_iterator&gt; 
    582 <span class=
    583 "keyword">typename</span> std::iterator_traits&lt;octet_iterator&gt;::difference_type distance (octet_iterator first, octet_iterator last);
    584    
    585 </pre>
    586     <p>
    587       <code>octet_iterator</code>: an input iterator.<br>
    588       <code>first</code>: an iterator to a beginning of a UTF-8 encoded code point.<br>
    589       <code>last</code>: an iterator to a "post-end" of the last UTF-8 encoded code
    590       point in the sequence we are trying to determine the length. It can be the
    591       beginning of a new code point, or not.<br>
    592        <span class="return_value">Return value</span> the distance between the iterators,
    593       in code points.
    594     </p>
    595     <p>
    596       Example of use:
    597     </p>
    598 <pre>
    599 <span class="keyword">char</span>* twochars = <span class=
    600 "literal">"\xe6\x97\xa5\xd1\x88"</span>;
    601 size_t dist = utf8::distance(twochars, twochars + <span class="literal">5</span>);
    602 assert (dist == <span class="literal">2</span>);
    603 </pre>
    604     <p>
    605       This function is used to find the length (in code points) of a UTF-8 encoded
    606       string. The reason it is called <em>distance</em>, rather than, say,
    607       <em>length</em> is mainly because developers are used that <em>length</em> is an
    608       O(1) function. Computing the length of an UTF-8 string is a linear operation, and
    609       it looked better to model it after <code>std::distance</code> algorithm.
    610     </p>
    611     <p>
    612       In case of an invalid UTF-8 seqence, a <code>utf8::invalid_utf8</code> exception is
    613       thrown. If <code>last</code> does not point to the past-of-end of a UTF-8 seqence,
    614       a <code>utf8::not_enough_room</code> exception is thrown.
    615     </p>
    616     <h4>
    617       utf8::utf16to8
    618     </h4>
    619     <p class="version">
    620     Available in version 1.0 and later.
    621     </p>
    622     <p>
    623       Converts a UTF-16 encoded string to UTF-8.
    624     </p>
    625 <pre>
    626 <span class="keyword">template</span> &lt;<span class=
    627 "keyword">typename</span> u16bit_iterator, <span class=
    628 "keyword">typename</span> octet_iterator&gt;
    629 octet_iterator utf16to8 (u16bit_iterator start, u16bit_iterator end, octet_iterator result);
    630    
    631 </pre>
    632     <p>
    633       <code>u16bit_iterator</code>: an input iterator.<br>
    634       <code>octet_iterator</code>: an output iterator.<br>
    635       <code>start</code>: an iterator pointing to the beginning of the UTF-16 encoded
    636       string to convert.<br>
    637        <code>end</code>: an iterator pointing to pass-the-end of the UTF-16 encoded
    638       string to convert.<br>
    639        <code>result</code>: an output iterator to the place in the UTF-8 string where to
    640       append the result of conversion.<br>
    641        <span class="return_value">Return value</span>: An iterator pointing to the place
    642       after the appended UTF-8 string.
    643     </p>
    644     <p>
    645       Example of use:
    646     </p>
    647 <pre>
    648 <span class="keyword">unsigned short</span> utf16string[] = {<span class=
    649 "literal">0x41</span>, <span class="literal">0x0448</span>, <span class=
    650 "literal">0x65e5</span>, <span class="literal">0xd834</span>, <span class=
    651 "literal">0xdd1e</span>};
    652 vector&lt;<span class="keyword">unsigned char</span>&gt; utf8result;
    653 utf16to8(utf16string, utf16string + <span class=
    654 "literal">5</span>, back_inserter(utf8result));
    655 assert (utf8result.size() == <span class="literal">10</span>);    
    656 </pre>
    657     <p>
    658       In case of invalid UTF-16 sequence, a <code>utf8::invalid_utf16</code> exception is
    659       thrown.
    660     </p>
    661     <h4>
    662       utf8::utf8to16
    663     </h4>
    664     <p class="version">
    665     Available in version 1.0 and later.
    666     </p>
    667     <p>
    668       Converts an UTF-8 encoded string to UTF-16
    669     </p>
    670 <pre>
    671 <span class="keyword">template</span> &lt;<span class=
    672 "keyword">typename</span> u16bit_iterator, typename octet_iterator&gt;
    673 u16bit_iterator utf8to16 (octet_iterator start, octet_iterator end, u16bit_iterator result);
    674    
    675 </pre>
    676     <p>
    677       <code>octet_iterator</code>: an input iterator.<br>
    678       <code>u16bit_iterator</code>: an output iterator.<br>
    679       <code>start</code>: an iterator pointing to the beginning of the UTF-8 encoded
    680       string to convert. &lt; br /&gt; <code>end</code>: an iterator pointing to
    681       pass-the-end of the UTF-8 encoded string to convert.<br>
    682        <code>result</code>: an output iterator to the place in the UTF-16 string where to
    683       append the result of conversion.<br>
    684        <span class="return_value">Return value</span>: An iterator pointing to the place
    685       after the appended UTF-16 string.
    686     </p>
    687     <p>
    688       Example of use:
    689     </p>
    690 <pre>
    691 <span class="keyword">char</span> utf8_with_surrogates[] = <span class=
    692 "literal">"\xe6\x97\xa5\xd1\x88\xf0\x9d\x84\x9e"</span>;
    693 vector &lt;<span class="keyword">unsigned short</span>&gt; utf16result;
    694 utf8to16(utf8_with_surrogates, utf8_with_surrogates + <span class=
    695 "literal">9</span>, back_inserter(utf16result));
    696 assert (utf16result.size() == <span class="literal">4</span>);
    697 assert (utf16result[<span class="literal">2</span>] == <span class=
    698 "literal">0xd834</span>);
    699 assert (utf16result[<span class="literal">3</span>] == <span class=
    700 "literal">0xdd1e</span>);
    701 </pre>
    702     <p>
    703       In case of an invalid UTF-8 seqence, a <code>utf8::invalid_utf8</code> exception is
    704       thrown. If <code>end</code> does not point to the past-of-end of a UTF-8 seqence, a
    705       <code>utf8::not_enough_room</code> exception is thrown.
    706     </p>
    707     <h4>
    708       utf8::utf32to8
    709     </h4>
    710     <p class="version">
    711     Available in version 1.0 and later.
    712     </p>
    713     <p>
    714       Converts a UTF-32 encoded string to UTF-8.
    715     </p>
    716 <pre>
    717 <span class="keyword">template</span> &lt;<span class=
    718 "keyword">typename</span> octet_iterator, typename u32bit_iterator&gt;
    719 octet_iterator utf32to8 (u32bit_iterator start, u32bit_iterator end, octet_iterator result);
    720    
    721 </pre>
    722     <p>
    723       <code>octet_iterator</code>: an output iterator.<br>
    724       <code>u32bit_iterator</code>: an input iterator.<br>
    725       <code>start</code>: an iterator pointing to the beginning of the UTF-32 encoded
    726       string to convert.<br>
    727        <code>end</code>: an iterator pointing to pass-the-end of the UTF-32 encoded
    728       string to convert.<br>
    729        <code>result</code>: an output iterator to the place in the UTF-8 string where to
    730       append the result of conversion.<br>
    731        <span class="return_value">Return value</span>: An iterator pointing to the place
    732       after the appended UTF-8 string.
    733     </p>
    734     <p>
    735       Example of use:
    736     </p>
    737 <pre>
    738 <span class="keyword">int</span> utf32string[] = {<span class=
    739 "literal">0x448</span>, <span class="literal">0x65E5</span>, <span class=
    740 "literal">0x10346</span>, <span class="literal">0</span>};
    741 vector&lt;<span class="keyword">unsigned char</span>&gt; utf8result;
    742 utf32to8(utf32string, utf32string + <span class=
    743 "literal">3</span>, back_inserter(utf8result));
    744 assert (utf8result.size() == <span class="literal">9</span>);
    745 </pre>
    746     <p>
    747       In case of invalid UTF-32 string, a <code>utf8::invalid_code_point</code> exception
    748       is thrown.
    749     </p>
    750     <h4>
    751       utf8::utf8to32
    752     </h4>
    753     <p class="version">
    754     Available in version 1.0 and later.
    755     </p>
    756     <p>
    757       Converts a UTF-8 encoded string to UTF-32.
    758     </p>
    759 <pre>
    760 <span class="keyword">template</span> &lt;<span class=
    761 "keyword">typename</span> octet_iterator, <span class=
    762 "keyword">typename</span> u32bit_iterator&gt;
    763 u32bit_iterator utf8to32 (octet_iterator start, octet_iterator end, u32bit_iterator result);
    764    
    765 </pre>
    766     <p>
    767       <code>octet_iterator</code>: an input iterator.<br>
    768       <code>u32bit_iterator</code>: an output iterator.<br>
    769       <code>start</code>: an iterator pointing to the beginning of the UTF-8 encoded
    770       string to convert.<br>
    771        <code>end</code>: an iterator pointing to pass-the-end of the UTF-8 encoded string
    772       to convert.<br>
    773        <code>result</code>: an output iterator to the place in the UTF-32 string where to
    774       append the result of conversion.<br>
    775        <span class="return_value">Return value</span>: An iterator pointing to the place
    776       after the appended UTF-32 string.
    777     </p>
    778     <p>
    779       Example of use:
    780     </p>
    781 <pre>
    782 <span class="keyword">char</span>* twochars = <span class=
    783 "literal">"\xe6\x97\xa5\xd1\x88"</span>;
    784 vector&lt;<span class="keyword">int</span>&gt; utf32result;
    785 utf8to32(twochars, twochars + <span class=
    786 "literal">5</span>, back_inserter(utf32result));
    787 assert (utf32result.size() == <span class="literal">2</span>);
    788 </pre>
    789     <p>
    790       In case of an invalid UTF-8 seqence, a <code>utf8::invalid_utf8</code> exception is
    791       thrown. If <code>end</code> does not point to the past-of-end of a UTF-8 seqence, a
    792       <code>utf8::not_enough_room</code> exception is thrown.
    793     </p>
    794     <h4>
    795       utf8::find_invalid
    796     </h4>
    797     <p class="version">
    798     Available in version 1.0 and later.
    799     </p>
    800     <p>
    801       Detects an invalid sequence within a UTF-8 string.
    802     </p>
    803 <pre>
    804 <span class="keyword">template</span> &lt;<span class=
    805 "keyword">typename</span> octet_iterator&gt; 
    806 octet_iterator find_invalid(octet_iterator start, octet_iterator end);
    807 </pre>
    808     <p>
    809       <code>octet_iterator</code>: an input iterator.<br>
    810       <code>start</code>: an iterator pointing to the beginning of the UTF-8 string to
    811       test for validity.<br>
    812        <code>end</code>: an iterator pointing to pass-the-end of the UTF-8 string to test
    813       for validity.<br>
    814        <span class="return_value">Return value</span>: an iterator pointing to the first
    815       invalid octet in the UTF-8 string. In case none were found, equals
    816       <code>end</code>.
    817     </p>
    818     <p>
    819       Example of use:
    820     </p>
    821 <pre>
    822 <span class="keyword">char</span> utf_invalid[] = <span class=
    823 "literal">"\xe6\x97\xa5\xd1\x88\xfa"</span>;
    824 <span class=
    825 "keyword">char</span>* invalid = find_invalid(utf_invalid, utf_invalid + <span class=
    826 "literal">6</span>);
    827 assert (invalid == utf_invalid + <span class="literal">5</span>);
    828 </pre>
    829     <p>
    830       This function is typically used to make sure a UTF-8 string is valid before
    831       processing it with other functions. It is especially important to call it if before
    832       doing any of the <em>unchecked</em> operations on it.
    833     </p>
    834     <h4>
    835       utf8::is_valid
    836     </h4>
    837     <p class="version">
    838     Available in version 1.0 and later.
    839     </p>
    840     <p>
    841       Checks whether a sequence of octets is a valid UTF-8 string.
    842     </p>
    843 <pre>
    844 <span class="keyword">template</span> &lt;<span class=
    845 "keyword">typename</span> octet_iterator&gt; 
    846 <span class="keyword">bool</span> is_valid(octet_iterator start, octet_iterator end);
    847    
    848 </pre>
    849     <p>
    850       <code>octet_iterator</code>: an input iterator.<br>
    851       <code>start</code>: an iterator pointing to the beginning of the UTF-8 string to
    852       test for validity.<br>
    853        <code>end</code>: an iterator pointing to pass-the-end of the UTF-8 string to test
    854       for validity.<br>
    855        <span class="return_value">Return value</span>: <code>true</code> if the sequence
    856       is a valid UTF-8 string; <code>false</code> if not.
    857     </p>
    858     Example of use: 
    859 <pre>
    860 <span class="keyword">char</span> utf_invalid[] = <span class=
    861 "literal">"\xe6\x97\xa5\xd1\x88\xfa"</span>;
    862 <span class="keyword">bool</span> bvalid = is_valid(utf_invalid, utf_invalid + <span
    863 class="literal">6</span>);
    864 assert (bvalid == false);
    865 </pre>
    866     <p>
    867       <code>is_valid</code> is a shorthand for <code>find_invalid(start, end) ==
    868       end;</code>. You may want to use it to make sure that a byte seqence is a valid
    869       UTF-8 string without the need to know where it fails if it is not valid.
    870     </p>
    871     <h4>
    872       utf8::replace_invalid
    873     </h4>
    874     <p class="version">
    875     Available in version 2.0 and later.
    876     </p>
    877     <p>
    878       Replaces all invalid UTF-8 sequences within a string with a replacement marker.
    879     </p>
    880 <pre>
    881 <span class="keyword">template</span> &lt;<span class=
    882 "keyword">typename</span> octet_iterator, <span class=
    883 "keyword">typename</span> output_iterator&gt;
    884 output_iterator replace_invalid(octet_iterator start, octet_iterator end, output_iterator out, uint32_t replacement);
    885 <span class="keyword">template</span> &lt;<span class=
    886 "keyword">typename</span> octet_iterator, <span class=
    887 "keyword">typename</span> output_iterator&gt;
    888 output_iterator replace_invalid(octet_iterator start, octet_iterator end, output_iterator out);
    889    
    890 </pre>
    891     <p>
    892       <code>octet_iterator</code>: an input iterator.<br>
    893       <code>output_iterator</code>: an output iterator.<br>
    894       <code>start</code>: an iterator pointing to the beginning of the UTF-8 string to
    895       look for invalid UTF-8 sequences.<br>
    896        <code>end</code>: an iterator pointing to pass-the-end of the UTF-8 string to look
    897       for invalid UTF-8 sequences.<br>
    898        <code>out</code>: An output iterator to the range where the result of replacement
    899       is stored.<br>
    900        <code>replacement</code>: A Unicode code point for the replacement marker. The
    901       version without this parameter assumes the value <code>0xfffd</code><br>
    902        <span class="return_value">Return value</span>: An iterator pointing to the place
    903       after the UTF-8 string with replaced invalid sequences.
    904     </p>
    905     <p>
    906       Example of use:
    907     </p>
    908 <pre>
    909 <span class="keyword">char</span> invalid_sequence[] = <span class=
    910 "literal">"a\x80\xe0\xa0\xc0\xaf\xed\xa0\x80z"</span>;
    911 vector&lt;<span class="keyword">char</span>&gt; replace_invalid_result;
    912 replace_invalid (invalid_sequence, invalid_sequence + sizeof(invalid_sequence), back_inserter(replace_invalid_result), <span
    913  class="literal">'?'</span>);
    914 bvalid = is_valid(replace_invalid_result.begin(), replace_invalid_result.end());
    915 assert (bvalid);
    916 <span class="keyword">char</span>* fixed_invalid_sequence = <span class=
    917 "literal">"a????z"</span>;
    918 assert (std::equal(replace_invalid_result.begin(), replace_invalid_result.end(), fixed_invalid_sequence));
    919 </pre>
    920     <p>
    921       <code>replace_invalid</code> does not perform in-place replacement of invalid
    922       sequences. Rather, it produces a copy of the original string with the invalid
    923       sequences replaced with a replacement marker. Therefore, <code>out</code> must not
    924       be in the <code>[start, end]</code> range.
    925     </p>
    926     <p>
    927       If <code>end</code> does not point to the past-of-end of a UTF-8 sequence, a
    928       <code>utf8::not_enough_room</code> exception is thrown.
    929     </p>
    930     <h4>
    931       utf8::starts_with_bom
    932     </h4>
    933     <p class="version">
    934     Available in version 2.3 and later. Relaces deprecated <code>is_bom()</code> function.
    935     </p>
    936     <p>
    937       Checks whether an octet sequence starts with a UTF-8 byte order mark (BOM)
    938     </p>
    939 <pre>
    940 <span class="keyword">template</span> &lt;<span class=
    941 "keyword">typename</span> octet_iterator&gt; 
    942 <span class="keyword">bool</span> starts_with_bom (octet_iterator it, octet_iterator end);
    943 </pre>
    944     <p>
    945       <code>octet_iterator</code>: an input iterator.<br>
    946       <code>it</code>: beginning of the octet sequence to check<br>
    947       <code>end</code>: pass-end of the sequence to check<br>
    948        <span class="return_value">Return value</span>: <code>true</code> if the sequence
    949       starts with a UTF-8 byte order mark; <code>false</code> if not.
    950     </p>
    951     <p>
    952       Example of use:
    953     </p>
    954 <pre>
    955 <span class="keyword">unsigned char</span> byte_order_mark[] = {<span class=
    956 "literal">0xef</span>, <span class="literal">0xbb</span>, <span class=
    957 "literal">0xbf</span>};
    958 <span class="keyword">bool</span> bbom = starts_with_bom(byte_order_mark, byte_order_mark + <span class="keyword">sizeof</span>(byte_order_mark));
    959 assert (bbom == <span class="literal">true</span>);
    960 </pre>
    961     <p>
    962       The typical use of this function is to check the first three bytes of a file. If
    963       they form the UTF-8 BOM, we want to skip them before processing the actual UTF-8
    964       encoded text.
    965     </p>
    966     <h4>
    967       utf8::is_bom
    968     </h4>
    969     <p class="version">
    970     Available in version 1.0 and later. Deprecated in version 2.3. <code>starts_with_bom()</code> should be used
    971     instead.
    972     </p>
    973     <p>
    974       Checks whether a sequence of three octets is a UTF-8 byte order mark (BOM)
    975     </p>
    976 <pre>
    977 <span class="keyword">template</span> &lt;<span class=
    978 "keyword">typename</span> octet_iterator&gt; 
    979 <span class="keyword">bool</span> is_bom (octet_iterator it); <span class="comment"> // Deprecated</span>
    980 </pre>
    981     <p>
    982       <code>octet_iterator</code>: an input iterator.<br>
    983       <code>it</code>: beginning of the 3-octet sequence to check<br>
    984        <span class="return_value">Return value</span>: <code>true</code> if the sequence
    985       is UTF-8 byte order mark; <code>false</code> if not.
    986     </p>
    987     <p>
    988       Example of use:
    989     </p>
    990 <pre>
    991 <span class="keyword">unsigned char</span> byte_order_mark[] = {<span class=
    992 "literal">0xef</span>, <span class="literal">0xbb</span>, <span class=
    993 "literal">0xbf</span>};
    994 <span class="keyword">bool</span> bbom = is_bom(byte_order_mark);
    995 assert (bbom == <span class="literal">true</span>);
    996 </pre>
    997     <p>
    998       The typical use of this function is to check the first three bytes of a file. If
    999       they form the UTF-8 BOM, we want to skip them before processing the actual UTF-8
   1000       encoded text.
   1001     </p>
   1002     <p>
   1003       If a sequence is 
   1004       shorter than three bytes, an invalid iterator will be dereferenced. Therefore, this function is deprecated
   1005       in favor of <code>starts_with_bom()</code>that takes the end of sequence as an argument.
   1006     </p>
   1007     <h3 id="typesutf8">
   1008       Types From utf8 Namespace
   1009     </h3>
   1010     <h4>utf8::exception
   1011     </h4>
   1012     <p class="version">
   1013     Available in version 2.3 and later.
   1014     </p>
   1015     <p>
   1016     Base class for the exceptions thrown by UTF CPP library functions.
   1017     </p>
   1018 <pre>
   1019 <span class="keyword">class</span> exception : <span class="keyword">public</span> std::exception {};
   1020 </pre>
   1021     <p>
   1022     Example of use:
   1023     </p>
   1024 <pre>
   1025 <span class="keyword">try</span> {
   1026   code_that_uses_utf_cpp_library();
   1027 }
   1028 <span class="keyword">catch</span>(<span class="keyword">const</span> utf8::exception&amp; utfcpp_ex) {
   1029   cerr &lt;&lt; utfcpp_ex.what();
   1030 }
   1031 </pre>
   1032     
   1033     <h4>utf8::invalid_code_point
   1034     </h4>
   1035     <p class="version">
   1036     Available in version 1.0 and later.
   1037     </p>
   1038     <p>
   1039     Thrown by UTF8 CPP functions such as <code>advance</code> and <code>next</code> if an UTF-8 sequence represents and invalid code point.
   1040     </p>
   1041 
   1042 <pre>
   1043 <span class="keyword">class</span> invalid_code_point : <span class="keyword">public</span> exception {
   1044 <span class="keyword">public</span>: 
   1045     uint32_t code_point() <span class="keyword">const</span>;
   1046 };
   1047 
   1048 </pre>
   1049     <p>
   1050     Member function <code>code_point()</code> can be used to determine the invalid code point that
   1051     caused the exception to be thrown.
   1052     </p>
   1053     <h4>utf8::invalid_utf8
   1054     </h4>
   1055     <p class="version">
   1056     Available in version 1.0 and later.
   1057     </p>
   1058     <p>
   1059     Thrown by UTF8 CPP functions such as <code>next</code> and <code>prior</code> if an invalid UTF-8 sequence
   1060     is detected during decoding.
   1061     </p>
   1062 
   1063 <pre>
   1064 <span class="keyword">class</span> invalid_utf8 : <span class="keyword">public</span> exception {
   1065 <span class="keyword">public</span>: 
   1066     uint8_t utf8_octet() <span class="keyword">const</span>;
   1067 };
   1068 </pre>
   1069 
   1070     <p>
   1071     Member function <code>utf8_octet()</code> can be used to determine the beginning of the byte 
   1072     sequence that caused the exception to be thrown.
   1073     </p>
   1074 </pre>
   1075     <h4>utf8::invalid_utf16
   1076     </h4>
   1077     <p class="version">
   1078     Available in version 1.0 and later.
   1079     </p>
   1080     <p>
   1081     Thrown by UTF8 CPP function <code>utf16to8</code> if an invalid UTF-16 sequence
   1082     is detected during decoding.
   1083     </p>
   1084 
   1085 <pre>
   1086 <span class="keyword">class</span> invalid_utf16 : <span class="keyword">public</span> exception {
   1087 <span class="keyword">public</span>: 
   1088     uint16_t utf16_word() <span class="keyword">const</span>;
   1089 };
   1090 </pre>
   1091 
   1092     <p>
   1093     Member function <code>utf16_word()</code> can be used to determine the UTF-16 code unit 
   1094     that caused the exception to be thrown.
   1095     </p>
   1096     <h4>utf8::not_enough_room
   1097     </h4>
   1098     <p class="version">
   1099     Available in version 1.0 and later.
   1100     </p>
   1101     <p>
   1102     Thrown by UTF8 CPP functions such as <code>next</code> if the end of the decoded UTF-8 sequence
   1103     was reached before the code point was decoded.
   1104     </p>
   1105 
   1106 <pre>
   1107 <span class="keyword">class</span> not_enough_room : <span class="keyword">public</span> exception {};
   1108 </pre>
   1109     <h4>
   1110       utf8::iterator
   1111     </h4>
   1112     <p class="version">
   1113     Available in version 2.0 and later.
   1114     </p>
   1115     <p>
   1116       Adapts the underlying octet iterator to iterate over the sequence of code points,
   1117       rather than raw octets.
   1118     </p>
   1119 <pre>
   1120 <span class="keyword">template</span> &lt;<span class="keyword">typename</span> octet_iterator&gt;
   1121 <span class="keyword">class</span> iterator;
   1122 </pre>
   1123     
   1124     <h5>Member functions</h5>
   1125       <dl>
   1126       <dt><code>iterator();</code> <dd> the deafult constructor; the underlying <code>octet_iterator</code> is
   1127       constructed with its default constructor.
   1128       <dt><code><span class="keyword">explicit</span> iterator (const octet_iterator&amp; octet_it, 
   1129                          const octet_iterator&amp; range_start,
   1130                          const octet_iterator&amp; range_end);</code> <dd> a constructor 
   1131       that initializes the underlying <code>octet_iterator</code> with <code>octet_it</code>
   1132       and sets the range in which the iterator is considered valid.
   1133       <dt><code>octet_iterator base () <span class="keyword">const</span>;</code> <dd> returns the 
   1134       underlying <code>octet_iterator</code>.
   1135       <dt><code>uint32_t operator * () <span class="keyword">const</span>;</code> <dd> decodes the utf-8 sequence
   1136       the underlying <code>octet_iterator</code> is pointing to and returns the code point.
   1137       <dt><code><span class="keyword">bool operator</span> == (const iterator&amp; rhs)
   1138       <span class="keyword">const</span>;</code> <dd> returns <span class="keyword">true</span>
   1139       if the two underlaying iterators are equal.
   1140       <dt><code><span class="keyword">bool operator</span> != (const iterator&amp; rhs)
   1141       <span class="keyword">const</span>;</code> <dd> returns <span class="keyword">true</span>
   1142       if the two underlaying iterators are not equal.
   1143       <dt><code>iterator&amp; <span class="keyword">operator</span> ++ (); </code> <dd> the prefix increment - moves
   1144       the iterator to the next UTF-8 encoded code point.
   1145       <dt><code>iterator <span class="keyword">operator</span> ++ (<span class="keyword">int</span>); </code> <dd>
   1146       the postfix increment - moves the iterator to the next UTF-8 encoded code point and returns the current one.
   1147       <dt><code>iterator&amp; <span class="keyword">operator</span> -- (); </code> <dd> the prefix decrement - moves
   1148       the iterator to the previous UTF-8 encoded code point.
   1149       <dt><code>iterator <span class="keyword">operator</span> -- (<span class="keyword">int</span>); </code> <dd>
   1150       the postfix decrement - moves the iterator to the previous UTF-8 encoded code point and returns the current one.
   1151       </dl>
   1152       <p>
   1153       Example of use:
   1154       </p>
   1155 <pre>
   1156 <span class="keyword">char</span>* threechars = <span class="literal">"\xf0\x90\x8d\x86\xe6\x97\xa5\xd1\x88"</span>;
   1157 utf8::iterator&lt;<span class="keyword">char</span>*&gt; it(threechars, threechars, threechars + <span class="literal">9</span>);
   1158 utf8::iterator&lt;<span class="keyword">char</span>*&gt; it2 = it;
   1159 assert (it2 == it);
   1160 assert (*it == <span class="literal">0x10346</span>);
   1161 assert (*(++it) == <span class="literal">0x65e5</span>);
   1162 assert ((*it++) == <span class="literal">0x65e5</span>);
   1163 assert (*it == <span class="literal">0x0448</span>);
   1164 assert (it != it2);
   1165 utf8::iterator&lt;<span class="keyword">char</span>*&gt; endit (threechars + <span class="literal">9</span>, threechars, threechars + <span class="literal">9</span>);  
   1166 assert (++it == endit);
   1167 assert (*(--it) == <span class="literal">0x0448</span>);
   1168 assert ((*it--) == <span class="literal">0x0448</span>);
   1169 assert (*it == <span class="literal">0x65e5</span>);
   1170 assert (--it == utf8::iterator&lt;<span class="keyword">char</span>*&gt;(threechars, threechars, threechars + <span class="literal">9</span>));
   1171 assert (*it == <span class="literal">0x10346</span>);
   1172 </pre>
   1173       <p>
   1174       The purpose of <code>utf8::iterator</code> adapter is to enable easy iteration as well as the use of STL
   1175       algorithms with UTF-8 encoded strings. Increment and decrement operators are implemented in terms of 
   1176       <code>utf8::next()</code> and <code>utf8::prior()</code> functions. 
   1177       </p>
   1178       <p>
   1179       Note that <code>utf8::iterator</code> adapter is a checked iterator. It operates on the range specified in
   1180       the constructor; any attempt to go out of that range will result in an exception. Even the comparison operators
   1181       require both iterator object to be constructed against the same range - otherwise an exception is thrown. Typically,
   1182       the range will be determined by sequence container functions <code>begin</code> and <code>end</code>, i.e.:
   1183       </p>
   1184 <pre>
   1185 std::string s = <span class="literal">"example"</span>;
   1186 utf8::iterator i (s.begin(), s.begin(), s.end());
   1187 </pre>
   1188     <h3 id="fununchecked">
   1189       Functions From utf8::unchecked Namespace
   1190     </h3>
   1191     <h4>
   1192       utf8::unchecked::append
   1193     </h4>
   1194     <p class="version">
   1195     Available in version 1.0 and later.
   1196     </p>
   1197     <p>
   1198       Encodes a 32 bit code point as a UTF-8 sequence of octets and appends the sequence
   1199       to a UTF-8 string.
   1200     </p>
   1201 <pre>
   1202 <span class="keyword">template</span> &lt;<span class=
   1203 "keyword">typename</span> octet_iterator&gt;
   1204 octet_iterator append(uint32_t cp, octet_iterator result);
   1205    
   1206 </pre>
   1207     <p>
   1208       <code>cp</code>: A 32 bit integer representing a code point to append to the
   1209       sequence.<br>
   1210        <code>result</code>: An output iterator to the place in the sequence where to
   1211       append the code point.<br>
   1212        <span class="return_value">Return value</span>: An iterator pointing to the place
   1213       after the newly appended sequence.
   1214     </p>
   1215     <p>
   1216       Example of use:
   1217     </p>
   1218 <pre>
   1219 <span class="keyword">unsigned char</span> u[<span class="literal">5</span>] = {<span
   1220 class="literal">0</span>,<span class="literal">0</span>,<span class=
   1221 "literal">0</span>,<span class="literal">0</span>,<span class="literal">0</span>};
   1222 <span class="keyword">unsigned char</span>* end = unchecked::append(<span class=
   1223 "literal">0x0448</span>, u);
   1224 assert (u[<span class="literal">0</span>] == <span class=
   1225 "literal">0xd1</span> &amp;&amp; u[<span class="literal">1</span>] == <span class=
   1226 "literal">0x88</span> &amp;&amp; u[<span class="literal">2</span>] == <span class=
   1227 "literal">0</span> &amp;&amp; u[<span class="literal">3</span>] == <span class=
   1228 "literal">0</span> &amp;&amp; u[<span class="literal">4</span>] == <span class=
   1229 "literal">0</span>);
   1230 </pre>
   1231     <p>
   1232       This is a faster but less safe version of <code>utf8::append</code>. It does not
   1233       check for validity of the supplied code point, and may produce an invalid UTF-8
   1234       sequence.
   1235     </p>
   1236     <h4>
   1237       utf8::unchecked::next
   1238     </h4>
   1239     <p class="version">
   1240     Available in version 1.0 and later.
   1241     </p>
   1242     <p>
   1243       Given the iterator to the beginning of a UTF-8 sequence, it returns the code point
   1244       and moves the iterator to the next position.
   1245     </p>
   1246 <pre>
   1247 <span class="keyword">template</span> &lt;<span class=
   1248 "keyword">typename</span> octet_iterator&gt;
   1249 uint32_t next(octet_iterator&amp; it);
   1250    
   1251 </pre>
   1252     <p>
   1253       <code>it</code>: a reference to an iterator pointing to the beginning of an UTF-8
   1254       encoded code point. After the function returns, it is incremented to point to the
   1255       beginning of the next code point.<br>
   1256        <span class="return_value">Return value</span>: the 32 bit representation of the
   1257       processed UTF-8 code point.
   1258     </p>
   1259     <p>
   1260       Example of use:
   1261     </p>
   1262 <pre>
   1263 <span class="keyword">char</span>* twochars = <span class=
   1264 "literal">"\xe6\x97\xa5\xd1\x88"</span>;
   1265 <span class="keyword">char</span>* w = twochars;
   1266 <span class="keyword">int</span> cp = unchecked::next(w);
   1267 assert (cp == <span class="literal">0x65e5</span>);
   1268 assert (w == twochars + <span class="literal">3</span>);
   1269 </pre>
   1270     <p>
   1271       This is a faster but less safe version of <code>utf8::next</code>. It does not
   1272       check for validity of the supplied UTF-8 sequence.
   1273     </p>
   1274     <h4>
   1275       utf8::unchecked::peek_next
   1276     </h4>
   1277     <p class="version">
   1278     Available in version 2.1 and later.
   1279     </p>
   1280     <p>
   1281       Given the iterator to the beginning of a UTF-8 sequence, it returns the code point.
   1282     </p>
   1283 <pre>
   1284 <span class="keyword">template</span> &lt;<span class=
   1285 "keyword">typename</span> octet_iterator&gt;
   1286 uint32_t peek_next(octet_iterator it);
   1287    
   1288 </pre>
   1289     <p>
   1290       <code>it</code>: an iterator pointing to the beginning of an UTF-8
   1291       encoded code point.<br>
   1292        <span class="return_value">Return value</span>: the 32 bit representation of the
   1293       processed UTF-8 code point.
   1294     </p>
   1295     <p>
   1296       Example of use:
   1297     </p>
   1298 <pre>
   1299 <span class="keyword">char</span>* twochars = <span class=
   1300 "literal">"\xe6\x97\xa5\xd1\x88"</span>;
   1301 <span class="keyword">char</span>* w = twochars;
   1302 <span class="keyword">int</span> cp = unchecked::peek_next(w);
   1303 assert (cp == <span class="literal">0x65e5</span>);
   1304 assert (w == twochars);
   1305 </pre>
   1306     <p>
   1307       This is a faster but less safe version of <code>utf8::peek_next</code>. It does not
   1308       check for validity of the supplied UTF-8 sequence.
   1309     </p>
   1310     <h4>
   1311       utf8::unchecked::prior
   1312     </h4>
   1313     <p class="version">
   1314     Available in version 1.02 and later.
   1315     </p>
   1316     <p>
   1317       Given a reference to an iterator pointing to an octet in a UTF-8 seqence, it
   1318       decreases the iterator until it hits the beginning of the previous UTF-8 encoded
   1319       code point and returns the 32 bits representation of the code point.
   1320     </p>
   1321 <pre>
   1322 <span class="keyword">template</span> &lt;<span class=
   1323 "keyword">typename</span> octet_iterator&gt;
   1324 uint32_t prior(octet_iterator&amp; it);
   1325    
   1326 </pre>
   1327     <p>
   1328       <code>it</code>: a reference pointing to an octet within a UTF-8 encoded string.
   1329       After the function returns, it is decremented to point to the beginning of the
   1330       previous code point.<br>
   1331        <span class="return_value">Return value</span>: the 32 bit representation of the
   1332       previous code point.
   1333     </p>
   1334     <p>
   1335       Example of use:
   1336     </p>
   1337 <pre>
   1338 <span class="keyword">char</span>* twochars = <span class=
   1339 "literal">"\xe6\x97\xa5\xd1\x88"</span>;
   1340 <span class="keyword">char</span>* w = twochars + <span class="literal">3</span>;
   1341 <span class="keyword">int</span> cp = unchecked::prior (w);
   1342 assert (cp == <span class="literal">0x65e5</span>);
   1343 assert (w == twochars);
   1344 </pre>
   1345     <p>
   1346       This is a faster but less safe version of <code>utf8::prior</code>. It does not
   1347       check for validity of the supplied UTF-8 sequence and offers no boundary checking.
   1348     </p>
   1349     <h4>
   1350       utf8::unchecked::previous (deprecated, see utf8::unchecked::prior)
   1351     </h4>
   1352     <p class="version">
   1353     Deprecated in version 1.02 and later.
   1354     </p>
   1355     <p>
   1356       Given a reference to an iterator pointing to an octet in a UTF-8 seqence, it
   1357       decreases the iterator until it hits the beginning of the previous UTF-8 encoded
   1358       code point and returns the 32 bits representation of the code point.
   1359     </p>
   1360 <pre>
   1361 <span class="keyword">template</span> &lt;<span class=
   1362 "keyword">typename</span> octet_iterator&gt;
   1363 uint32_t previous(octet_iterator&amp; it);
   1364    
   1365 </pre>
   1366     <p>
   1367       <code>it</code>: a reference pointing to an octet within a UTF-8 encoded string.
   1368       After the function returns, it is decremented to point to the beginning of the
   1369       previous code point.<br>
   1370        <span class="return_value">Return value</span>: the 32 bit representation of the
   1371       previous code point.
   1372     </p>
   1373     <p>
   1374       Example of use:
   1375     </p>
   1376 <pre>
   1377 <span class="keyword">char</span>* twochars = <span class=
   1378 "literal">"\xe6\x97\xa5\xd1\x88"</span>;
   1379 <span class="keyword">char</span>* w = twochars + <span class="literal">3</span>;
   1380 <span class="keyword">int</span> cp = unchecked::previous (w);
   1381 assert (cp == <span class="literal">0x65e5</span>);
   1382 assert (w == twochars);
   1383 </pre>
   1384     <p>
   1385      The reason this function is deprecated is just the consistency with the "checked"
   1386      versions, where <code>prior</code> should be used instead of <code>previous</code>.
   1387      In fact, <code>unchecked::previous</code> behaves exactly the same as <code>
   1388      unchecked::prior</code>
   1389     </p>
   1390     <p>
   1391       This is a faster but less safe version of <code>utf8::previous</code>. It does not
   1392       check for validity of the supplied UTF-8 sequence and offers no boundary checking.
   1393     </p>
   1394     <h4>
   1395       utf8::unchecked::advance
   1396     </h4>
   1397     <p class="version">
   1398     Available in version 1.0 and later.
   1399     </p>
   1400     <p>
   1401       Advances an iterator by the specified number of code points within an UTF-8
   1402       sequence.
   1403     </p>
   1404 <pre>
   1405 <span class="keyword">template</span> &lt;<span class=
   1406 "keyword">typename</span> octet_iterator, typename distance_type&gt;
   1407 <span class="keyword">void</span> advance (octet_iterator&amp; it, distance_type n);
   1408    
   1409 </pre>
   1410     <p>
   1411       <code>it</code>: a reference to an iterator pointing to the beginning of an UTF-8
   1412       encoded code point. After the function returns, it is incremented to point to the
   1413       nth following code point.<br>
   1414        <code>n</code>: a positive integer that shows how many code points we want to
   1415       advance.<br>
   1416     </p>
   1417     <p>
   1418       Example of use:
   1419     </p>
   1420 <pre>
   1421 <span class="keyword">char</span>* twochars = <span class=
   1422 "literal">"\xe6\x97\xa5\xd1\x88"</span>;
   1423 <span class="keyword">char</span>* w = twochars;
   1424 unchecked::advance (w, <span class="literal">2</span>);
   1425 assert (w == twochars + <span class="literal">5</span>);
   1426 </pre>
   1427     <p>
   1428       This function works only "forward". In case of a negative <code>n</code>, there is
   1429       no effect.
   1430     </p>
   1431     <p>
   1432       This is a faster but less safe version of <code>utf8::advance</code>. It does not
   1433       check for validity of the supplied UTF-8 sequence and offers no boundary checking.
   1434     </p>
   1435     <h4>
   1436       utf8::unchecked::distance
   1437     </h4>
   1438     <p class="version">
   1439     Available in version 1.0 and later.
   1440     </p>
   1441     <p>
   1442       Given the iterators to two UTF-8 encoded code points in a seqence, returns the
   1443       number of code points between them.
   1444     </p>
   1445 <pre>
   1446 <span class="keyword">template</span> &lt;<span class=
   1447 "keyword">typename</span> octet_iterator&gt;
   1448 <span class=
   1449 "keyword">typename</span> std::iterator_traits&lt;octet_iterator&gt;::difference_type distance (octet_iterator first, octet_iterator last);
   1450 </pre>
   1451     <p>
   1452       <code>first</code>: an iterator to a beginning of a UTF-8 encoded code point.<br>
   1453        <code>last</code>: an iterator to a "post-end" of the last UTF-8 encoded code
   1454       point in the sequence we are trying to determine the length. It can be the
   1455       beginning of a new code point, or not.<br>
   1456        <span class="return_value">Return value</span> the distance between the iterators,
   1457       in code points.
   1458     </p>
   1459     <p>
   1460       Example of use:
   1461     </p>
   1462 <pre>
   1463 <span class="keyword">char</span>* twochars = <span class=
   1464 "literal">"\xe6\x97\xa5\xd1\x88"</span>;
   1465 size_t dist = utf8::unchecked::distance(twochars, twochars + <span class=
   1466 "literal">5</span>);
   1467 assert (dist == <span class="literal">2</span>);
   1468 </pre>
   1469     <p>
   1470       This is a faster but less safe version of <code>utf8::distance</code>. It does not
   1471       check for validity of the supplied UTF-8 sequence.
   1472     </p>
   1473     <h4>
   1474       utf8::unchecked::utf16to8
   1475     </h4>
   1476     <p class="version">
   1477     Available in version 1.0 and later.
   1478     </p>
   1479     <p>
   1480       Converts a UTF-16 encoded string to UTF-8.
   1481     </p>
   1482 <pre>
   1483 <span class="keyword">template</span> &lt;<span class=
   1484 "keyword">typename</span> u16bit_iterator, <span class=
   1485 "keyword">typename</span> octet_iterator&gt;
   1486 octet_iterator utf16to8 (u16bit_iterator start, u16bit_iterator end, octet_iterator result);
   1487    
   1488 </pre>
   1489     <p>
   1490       <code>start</code>: an iterator pointing to the beginning of the UTF-16 encoded
   1491       string to convert.<br>
   1492        <code>end</code>: an iterator pointing to pass-the-end of the UTF-16 encoded
   1493       string to convert.<br>
   1494        <code>result</code>: an output iterator to the place in the UTF-8 string where to
   1495       append the result of conversion.<br>
   1496        <span class="return_value">Return value</span>: An iterator pointing to the place
   1497       after the appended UTF-8 string.
   1498     </p>
   1499     <p>
   1500       Example of use:
   1501     </p>
   1502 <pre>
   1503 <span class="keyword">unsigned short</span> utf16string[] = {<span class=
   1504 "literal">0x41</span>, <span class="literal">0x0448</span>, <span class=
   1505 "literal">0x65e5</span>, <span class="literal">0xd834</span>, <span class=
   1506 "literal">0xdd1e</span>};
   1507 vector&lt;<span class="keyword">unsigned char</span>&gt; utf8result;
   1508 unchecked::utf16to8(utf16string, utf16string + <span class=
   1509 "literal">5</span>, back_inserter(utf8result));
   1510 assert (utf8result.size() == <span class="literal">10</span>);    
   1511 </pre>
   1512     <p>
   1513       This is a faster but less safe version of <code>utf8::utf16to8</code>. It does not
   1514       check for validity of the supplied UTF-16 sequence.
   1515     </p>
   1516     <h4>
   1517       utf8::unchecked::utf8to16
   1518     </h4>
   1519     <p class="version">
   1520     Available in version 1.0 and later.
   1521     </p>
   1522     <p>
   1523       Converts an UTF-8 encoded string to UTF-16
   1524     </p>
   1525 <pre>
   1526 <span class="keyword">template</span> &lt;<span class=
   1527 "keyword">typename</span> u16bit_iterator, typename octet_iterator&gt;
   1528 u16bit_iterator utf8to16 (octet_iterator start, octet_iterator end, u16bit_iterator result);
   1529    
   1530 </pre>
   1531     <p>
   1532       <code>start</code>: an iterator pointing to the beginning of the UTF-8 encoded
   1533       string to convert. &lt; br /&gt; <code>end</code>: an iterator pointing to
   1534       pass-the-end of the UTF-8 encoded string to convert.<br>
   1535        <code>result</code>: an output iterator to the place in the UTF-16 string where to
   1536       append the result of conversion.<br>
   1537        <span class="return_value">Return value</span>: An iterator pointing to the place
   1538       after the appended UTF-16 string.
   1539     </p>
   1540     <p>
   1541       Example of use:
   1542     </p>
   1543 <pre>
   1544 <span class="keyword">char</span> utf8_with_surrogates[] = <span class=
   1545 "literal">"\xe6\x97\xa5\xd1\x88\xf0\x9d\x84\x9e"</span>;
   1546 vector &lt;<span class="keyword">unsigned short</span>&gt; utf16result;
   1547 unchecked::utf8to16(utf8_with_surrogates, utf8_with_surrogates + <span class=
   1548 "literal">9</span>, back_inserter(utf16result));
   1549 assert (utf16result.size() == <span class="literal">4</span>);
   1550 assert (utf16result[<span class="literal">2</span>] == <span class=
   1551 "literal">0xd834</span>);
   1552 assert (utf16result[<span class="literal">3</span>] == <span class=
   1553 "literal">0xdd1e</span>);
   1554 </pre>
   1555     <p>
   1556       This is a faster but less safe version of <code>utf8::utf8to16</code>. It does not
   1557       check for validity of the supplied UTF-8 sequence.
   1558     </p>
   1559     <h4>
   1560       utf8::unchecked::utf32to8
   1561     </h4>
   1562     <p class="version">
   1563     Available in version 1.0 and later.
   1564     </p>
   1565     <p>
   1566       Converts a UTF-32 encoded string to UTF-8.
   1567     </p>
   1568 <pre>
   1569 <span class="keyword">template</span> &lt;<span class=
   1570 "keyword">typename</span> octet_iterator, <span class=
   1571 "keyword">typename</span> u32bit_iterator&gt;
   1572 octet_iterator utf32to8 (u32bit_iterator start, u32bit_iterator end, octet_iterator result);
   1573    
   1574 </pre>
   1575     <p>
   1576       <code>start</code>: an iterator pointing to the beginning of the UTF-32 encoded
   1577       string to convert.<br>
   1578        <code>end</code>: an iterator pointing to pass-the-end of the UTF-32 encoded
   1579       string to convert.<br>
   1580        <code>result</code>: an output iterator to the place in the UTF-8 string where to
   1581       append the result of conversion.<br>
   1582        <span class="return_value">Return value</span>: An iterator pointing to the place
   1583       after the appended UTF-8 string.
   1584     </p>
   1585     <p>
   1586       Example of use:
   1587     </p>
   1588 <pre>
   1589 <span class="keyword">int</span> utf32string[] = {<span class=
   1590 "literal">0x448</span>, <span class="literal">0x65e5</span>, <span class=
   1591 "literal">0x10346</span>, <span class="literal">0</span>};
   1592 vector&lt;<span class="keyword">unsigned char</span>&gt; utf8result;
   1593 utf32to8(utf32string, utf32string + <span class=
   1594 "literal">3</span>, back_inserter(utf8result));
   1595 assert (utf8result.size() == <span class="literal">9</span>);
   1596 </pre>
   1597     <p>
   1598       This is a faster but less safe version of <code>utf8::utf32to8</code>. It does not
   1599       check for validity of the supplied UTF-32 sequence.
   1600     </p>
   1601     <h4>
   1602       utf8::unchecked::utf8to32
   1603     </h4>
   1604     <p class="version">
   1605     Available in version 1.0 and later.
   1606     </p>
   1607     <p>
   1608       Converts a UTF-8 encoded string to UTF-32.
   1609     </p>
   1610 <pre>
   1611 <span class="keyword">template</span> &lt;<span class=
   1612 "keyword">typename</span> octet_iterator, typename u32bit_iterator&gt;
   1613 u32bit_iterator utf8to32 (octet_iterator start, octet_iterator end, u32bit_iterator result);
   1614    
   1615 </pre>
   1616     <p>
   1617       <code>start</code>: an iterator pointing to the beginning of the UTF-8 encoded
   1618       string to convert.<br>
   1619        <code>end</code>: an iterator pointing to pass-the-end of the UTF-8 encoded string
   1620       to convert.<br>
   1621        <code>result</code>: an output iterator to the place in the UTF-32 string where to
   1622       append the result of conversion.<br>
   1623        <span class="return_value">Return value</span>: An iterator pointing to the place
   1624       after the appended UTF-32 string.
   1625     </p>
   1626     <p>
   1627       Example of use:
   1628     </p>
   1629 <pre>
   1630 <span class="keyword">char</span>* twochars = <span class=
   1631 "literal">"\xe6\x97\xa5\xd1\x88"</span>;
   1632 vector&lt;<span class="keyword">int</span>&gt; utf32result;
   1633 unchecked::utf8to32(twochars, twochars + <span class=
   1634 "literal">5</span>, back_inserter(utf32result));
   1635 assert (utf32result.size() == <span class="literal">2</span>);
   1636 </pre>
   1637     <p>
   1638       This is a faster but less safe version of <code>utf8::utf8to32</code>. It does not
   1639       check for validity of the supplied UTF-8 sequence.
   1640     </p>
   1641     <h3 id="typesunchecked">
   1642       Types From utf8::unchecked Namespace
   1643     </h3>
   1644     <h4>
   1645       utf8::iterator
   1646     </h4>
   1647     <p class="version">
   1648     Available in version 2.0 and later.
   1649     </p>
   1650     <p>
   1651       Adapts the underlying octet iterator to iterate over the sequence of code points,
   1652       rather than raw octets.
   1653     </p>
   1654 <pre>
   1655 <span class="keyword">template</span> &lt;<span class="keyword">typename</span> octet_iterator&gt;
   1656 <span class="keyword">class</span> iterator;
   1657 </pre>
   1658     
   1659     <h5>Member functions</h5>
   1660       <dl>
   1661       <dt><code>iterator();</code> <dd> the deafult constructor; the underlying <code>octet_iterator</code> is
   1662       constructed with its default constructor.
   1663       <dt><code><span class="keyword">explicit</span> iterator (const octet_iterator&amp; octet_it); 
   1664                          </code> <dd> a constructor 
   1665       that initializes the underlying <code>octet_iterator</code> with <code>octet_it</code>
   1666       <dt><code>octet_iterator base () <span class="keyword">const</span>;</code> <dd> returns the 
   1667       underlying <code>octet_iterator</code>.
   1668       <dt><code>uint32_t operator * () <span class="keyword">const</span>;</code> <dd> decodes the utf-8 sequence
   1669       the underlying <code>octet_iterator</code> is pointing to and returns the code point.
   1670       <dt><code><span class="keyword">bool operator</span> == (const iterator&amp; rhs)
   1671       <span class="keyword">const</span>;</code> <dd> returns <span class="keyword">true</span>
   1672       if the two underlaying iterators are equal.
   1673       <dt><code><span class="keyword">bool operator</span> != (const iterator&amp; rhs)
   1674       <span class="keyword">const</span>;</code> <dd> returns <span class="keyword">true</span>
   1675       if the two underlaying iterators are not equal.
   1676       <dt><code>iterator&amp; <span class="keyword">operator</span> ++ (); </code> <dd> the prefix increment - moves
   1677       the iterator to the next UTF-8 encoded code point.
   1678       <dt><code>iterator <span class="keyword">operator</span> ++ (<span class="keyword">int</span>); </code> <dd>
   1679       the postfix increment - moves the iterator to the next UTF-8 encoded code point and returns the current one.
   1680       <dt><code>iterator&amp; <span class="keyword">operator</span> -- (); </code> <dd> the prefix decrement - moves
   1681       the iterator to the previous UTF-8 encoded code point.
   1682       <dt><code>iterator <span class="keyword">operator</span> -- (<span class="keyword">int</span>); </code> <dd>
   1683       the postfix decrement - moves the iterator to the previous UTF-8 encoded code point and returns the current one.
   1684       </dl>
   1685       <p>
   1686       Example of use:
   1687       </p>
   1688 <pre>
   1689 <span class="keyword">char</span>* threechars = <span class="literal">"\xf0\x90\x8d\x86\xe6\x97\xa5\xd1\x88"</span>;
   1690 utf8::unchecked::iterator&lt;<span class="keyword">char</span>*&gt; un_it(threechars);
   1691 utf8::unchecked::iterator&lt;<span class="keyword">char</span>*&gt; un_it2 = un_it;
   1692 assert (un_it2 == un_it);
   1693 assert (*un_it == <span class="literal">0x10346</span>);
   1694 assert (*(++un_it) == <span class="literal">0x65e5</span>);
   1695 assert ((*un_it++) == <span class="literal">0x65e5</span>);
   1696 assert (*un_it == <span class="literal">0x0448</span>);
   1697 assert (un_it != un_it2);
   1698 utf8::::unchecked::iterator&lt;<span class="keyword">char</span>*&gt; un_endit (threechars + <span class="literal">9</span>);  
   1699 assert (++un_it == un_endit);
   1700 assert (*(--un_it) == <span class="literal">0x0448</span>);
   1701 assert ((*un_it--) == <span class="literal">0x0448</span>);
   1702 assert (*un_it == <span class="literal">0x65e5</span>);
   1703 assert (--un_it == utf8::unchecked::iterator&lt;<span class="keyword">char</span>*&gt;(threechars));
   1704 assert (*un_it == <span class="literal">0x10346</span>);
   1705 </pre>
   1706       <p>
   1707       This is an unchecked version of <code>utf8::iterator</code>. It is faster in many cases, but offers
   1708       no validity or range checks.
   1709       </p>
   1710     <h2 id="points">
   1711       Points of interest
   1712     </h2>
   1713     <h4>
   1714       Design goals and decisions
   1715     </h4>
   1716     <p>
   1717       The library was designed to be:
   1718     </p>
   1719     <ol>
   1720       <li>
   1721         Generic: for better or worse, there are many C++ string classes out there, and
   1722         the library should work with as many of them as possible.
   1723       </li>
   1724       <li>
   1725         Portable: the library should be portable both accross different platforms and
   1726         compilers. The only non-portable code is a small section that declares unsigned
   1727         integers of different sizes: three typedefs. They can be changed by the users of
   1728         the library if they don't match their platform. The default setting should work
   1729         for Windows (both 32 and 64 bit), and most 32 bit and 64 bit Unix derivatives.
   1730       </li>
   1731       <li>
   1732         Lightweight: follow the "pay only for what you use" guideline.
   1733       </li>
   1734       <li>
   1735         Unintrusive: avoid forcing any particular design or even programming style on the
   1736         user. This is a library, not a framework.
   1737       </li>
   1738     </ol>
   1739     <h4>
   1740       Alternatives
   1741     </h4>
   1742     <p>
   1743       In case you want to look into other means of working with UTF-8 strings from C++,
   1744       here is the list of solutions I am aware of:
   1745     </p>
   1746     <ol>
   1747       <li>
   1748         <a href="http://icu.sourceforge.net/">ICU Library</a>. It is very powerful,
   1749         complete, feature-rich, mature, and widely used. Also big, intrusive,
   1750         non-generic, and doesn't play well with the Standard Library. I definitelly
   1751         recommend looking at ICU even if you don't plan to use it.
   1752       </li>
   1753       <li>
   1754         C++11 language and library features. Still far from complete, and not widely
   1755         supported by compiler vendors. 
   1756       </li>
   1757       <li>
   1758         <a href=
   1759         "http://www.gtkmm.org/gtkmm2/docs/tutorial/html/ch03s04.html">Glib::ustring</a>.
   1760         A class specifically made to work with UTF-8 strings, and also feel like
   1761         <code>std::string</code>. If you prefer to have yet another string class in your
   1762         code, it may be worth a look. Be aware of the licensing issues, though.
   1763       </li>
   1764       <li>
   1765         Platform dependent solutions: Windows and POSIX have functions to convert strings
   1766         from one encoding to another. That is only a subset of what my library offers,
   1767         but if that is all you need it may be good enough.
   1768       </li>
   1769     </ol>

   1779       </li>

   1784         <a href="http://www.cl.cam.ac.uk/~mgk25/unicode.html">UTF-8 and Unicode FAQ for
   1785         Unix/Linux</a>
   1786       </li>
